author: __lithp__
content:
> You can reconstruct either proof from the code itself

Absolutely! But I'm thinking about block propagation. If you're an intermediate node and you're stateless and you've received a witness which only includes the kate proof, you will not be able to forward the block to a stateless peer which wants to use the merkle proof

author: __lithp__
content: If you're an intermediate full node and you've received a witness with just the kate proof then you can reconstruct the merkle proof for your peers, but that requires reading from your local disk and will slow down block propagation.

author: thiago_crowdtainer
content: A question perhaps relevant for the community is how easy and how frequent can the commitment be updated: a person in the future might not trust a chain that is based on an aggregation made 100 years in the past. OTOH those who participated already won’t be interested in updating it again. So getting more participants can become a challenge over time if done too frequently. Is this a fair assessment or thing to worry about? Maybe there’s a way to automate it and use say, the validators signature to constantly update it?
